docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Our Op-Ed article on the ''designer drug'' law contains a misleading statement to the effect that some antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs mentioned are analogues of controlled substances. They are not, although most new antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs are analogues of existing ones. LESTER GRINSPOON, M.D. JAMES BAKALAR Boston, May 13, 1986

headline.main: Medication Plays a Real Role in Psychotherapy

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Our Op-Ed article on the ''designer drug'' law contains a misleading statement to the effect that some antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs mentioned are analogues of controlled substances. They are not, although most new...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like an ever tightening noose, Parkinson's disease slowly took over Meyer's life, turning it into a kind of torture and leaving him a prisoner. ''All his life, my husband never cried,'' his wife said, tears welling in the corners of her own eyes. ''But then he wouldn't stop crying. This was not my husband. It was something else, some monster.'' Day by day, the pain and the shaking on Meyer's right side increased. So did the stiffness. Drugs not only failed to help, but also caused nightmares that made him paranoid and turned him against his wife. So the couple stopped entertaining, and Meyer rarely left their New Jersey home.

headline.main: BRAIN SURGERY TECHNIQUE MAKES A COMEBACK

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CHARACTER FACTORY Baden-Powell and the Origins of the Boy Scout Movement. By Michael Rosenthal. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95. PERHAPS unfairly, I've always found scouting faintly ludicrous. My only two personal experiences of it were a bit odd and not really conducive to respect. Also, I can remember as a boy those photographs of King George VI - ridiculous, like all adult Scouts, in baggy shorts and wide-brimmed hat - looking as if he couldn't tie a knot to save his life. Robert Stephenson Smyth Baden-Powell, first Baron Baden-Powell, the subject of Michael Rosenthal's new study, could tie knots. Born in 1857, he went to Charterhouse school in 1870. Typical of his period, he despised work - ''often sleeps in class'' - and loved games. Two hints of the future: he was a successful schoolboy actor; he was a solitary, who loved creeping about the Godalming countryside having fantasies that he was an American Indian or a trapper.
